thread.title_full: 'He's such a voilatile enigma, we don't know what he will do' - Northumbria US expert on Trump win

author: Hannah Graham
title: 'He's such a voilatile enigma, we don't know what he will do' - Northumbria US expert on Trump win
text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A Trump Government will look to build bridges with the UK, says a Northumbria University US expert , but it’s hard to say what the new President’s policies will be. 
As a US citizen and a reader in American history, Professor Michael Cullinane watched the results roll in through the night. 
He described the moment he realised what the result would be. 
“It’s pretty crazy to imagine that all the predictions were wrong,” he said. 
“I’m shocked, and then I’m concerned about where we go from here. 
“We’re looking at probably a very nationalistic, isolationist, regressive Government. 
“It’s going to take some time for this to work itself out, especially because of the way Trump captured so many states thought would go to Clinton, or at least be close.” Donald Trump and Reince Priebus (Photo: Joe Raedle/Getty Images) 
So, what is Trump’s America going to look like, and how will the UK, and the North East, be affected? 
Prof Cullinane said it’s still not clear how Trump will behave on the world stage, but he’s likely to reach out to a post-Brexit Britain. 
He said: “It’s similar to the feeling after Brexit, we just don’t know how negotiations are going to play out. 
“We’re talking about trade, business contracts, the military — he’s such a volatile enigma, we don’t know what he will do.” Read More 
Trump has said in the past that, after leaving the EU, Britain “would not be at the back of the queue” for trade deals with America under his presidency. 
Prof Cullinane says he’s likely to reach out to the UK. 
He said: “He’s certainly going to want to build bridges, he will need some friend and allies.” 
But the he warned that our politicians will have to negotiate hard to make sure any relationship with Trump’s America is a favourable one for the UK. 
And as for what Trump will do next? 
The professor’s guess is as good as yours. Share
